childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1990-2002

Children born in 1990 arrived into what historians would later call the "unipolar moment" — the brief period after the Cold War ended and before anyone figured out what came next. Germany had just reunified. Nelson Mandela had just walked free. The Soviet Union would collapse before this cohort's second birthday. For their parents, who'd spent decades under the shadow of nuclear annihilation, the world suddenly seemed less dangerous. For the babies, the world was simply the world — they had no Cold War to compare it to, no before and after, just the humming present of early-1990s American life.

That life, for most of this cohort, was suburban and stable. The Clinton years coincided almost exactly with their elementary school experience, and the longest economic expansion in American history provided the backdrop for their childhood. Their parents had jobs. Houses were getting bigger. The family computer arrived sometime around first or second grade — a hulking beige machine in the spare room that ran educational software and occasionally connected to the internet through a phone line that screamed. The domestic atmosphere was one of quiet, spreading prosperity, the kind that showed up not in grand gestures but in small ones: a new car, a kitchen renovation, talk of vacation.

The school experience for this cohort fell in a narrow window between two eras. Recess still existed and still mattered. Art and music still had their own teachers and their own rooms. The overhead projector was the dominant classroom technology. But standardized testing was arriving with increasing urgency, and the curriculum was beginning to bend toward measurable outcomes. Children still wrote in cursive, still memorized multiplication tables through repetition, still did science projects that involved poster board and glitter. The analog classroom was intact, but its days were numbered, and the adults could sense it even if the children couldn't.

The neighborhood of their childhood was safe — or at least felt safe, which was almost the same thing. Crime rates were falling through the 1990s, but the perception of danger was rising, driven by 24-hour cable news and a culture that had decided children were perpetually at risk. Milk carton faces. Amber Alerts. Stranger danger as a permanent posture rather than a specific warning. This cohort played outside, but less than their parents had. They rode bikes, but within tighter boundaries. The leash was lengthening in some ways and shortening in others.

At nine, Columbine happened. For this cohort — fourth-graders, old enough to understand that students had been shot in their school — the event landed with seismic force. Lockdown drills began. Conversations about school safety that had been abstract became urgent and specific. The assumption that school was a place of unconditional safety cracked. For the rest of their school years, a part of their consciousness would be devoted to exits, to hiding places, to the question that adults kept asking but never answered satisfactorily: could it happen here?

At eleven, on September 11, this cohort was in sixth grade. They watched the towers fall on classroom televisions, or they were sent home and watched with their parents. Either way, the event was comprehensible to them in a way it wasn't for younger children — they understood death, they understood enemies, they understood that the adults around them were genuinely afraid. The rest of their childhood — what little remained — would unfold under the long shadow of that morning. Flag pins appeared on every lapel. Security lines appeared at every airport. The country they'd grown up in became a different country, and their childhood became a story about the before.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials born in 1990 are part of the 1981-1996 cohort according to Pew Research's definition that finally stuck after years of boundary arguments. This generation numbers roughly 72 million in the US—the largest generation until Gen Z started catching up and will probably surpass them soon.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. Those born in 1990 were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. Old enough to understand planes hitting buildings meant people dying. Young enough for that morning to fundamentally rewire their sense of safety forever. The pre-9/11 world they remember hazily—airports where families waited at gates, security that felt like formality—that became ancient history overnight. Everything after was color-coded threat levels, shoe removal at checkpoints, forever wars.

They entered adulthood just as the 2008 financial crisis imploded the economy. They graduated high school in 2008, which meant entering college or the workforce as Lehman Brothers collapsed and the job market cratered. The timing was brutal. The social contract their parents described—work hard, stay loyal, get rewarded with stability—turned out to be fairy tale from a different economy.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. Millennial. The word became a slur before they hit thirty—shorthand for entitled, lazy, participation-trophy-obsessed. Never mind that they're the most educated generation in American history. Never mind that they entered the workforce during the worst economy since the Great Depression. Never mind that housing costs tripled while wages grew single digits. The narrative was written before they could speak for themselves.

They're sandwiched between Gen X (who got careers and houses before the floor fell out) and Gen Z (who never expected the floor to exist). They're old enough to remember optimism, young enough to know it's not coming back. That specific disappointment—believing things could work, then watching them not—shapes everything.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1990 saw Dances with Wolves win Best Picture and Pretty Woman turn Julia Roberts into America's sweetheart through the power of shopping montages and improbable romance. Kevin McCallister got left home alone, teaching a generation that childhood independence meant elaborate violence against burglars. The Simpsons started its endless run as a weekly series—it would outlast childhood, adolescence, twenties, thirties, showing no signs of stopping ever.

Musically, 1990 was the hinge between decades. MC Hammer told everyone they couldn't touch this, in pants that ensured nobody could touch anything. Vanilla Ice was ripping off Queen basslines with 'Ice Ice Baby.' Madonna was voguing. Sinéad O'Connor tore up a photo of the Pope on live television and became either a hero or a villain depending on who was asked. Hair metal was dying. Grunge was about to be born—Nirvana's 'Nevermind' would arrive when they were one year old.

Childhood soundtrack was peak '90s: Spice Girls telling them what they want (what they really really want), boy bands competing for loyalty—Backstreet versus *NSYNC was a real choice people made and defended. They probably had a Discman that skipped every time they walked, which defeated the purpose of portable music but they made it work. MTV still played music videos. TRL was appointment television. They learned what 'number one' meant by watching Carson Daly count down.

TV in formative years was Friends, Seinfeld, The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air. Saturday mornings meant Nickelodeon—Rugrats with its baby philosophy, Doug with his anxious journal entries, Hey Arnold with his football head. After school was Cartoon Network—Dexter's Lab, Johnny Bravo, Powerpuff Girls. They watched TV on a schedule because DVR didn't exist yet. Miss an episode, wait for summer reruns.

Middle school years coincided perfectly with Harry Potter's cultural domination. At eleven, the first book came out in the US—the same age as Harry starting Hogwarts. The series was demographically engineered for them, each book releasing as they aged alongside the characters. They probably felt like J.K. Rowling wrote it specifically for their generation, because demographically, she did.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1990 saw Tim Berners-Lee invent the World Wide Web, the Hubble Space Telescope launch into orbit, and the first GPS satellites go operational. The technological infrastructure that would define an entire existence was being assembled while children were learning to crawl. This generation is exactly as old as the modern internet, and they've grown up together.

The relationship with technology is unique because they remember both sides of the digital divide with clarity. They know what it's like to research a school paper using actual books in an actual library, flipping through card catalogs, waiting for microfiche to load. They also know what it's like to have the entire sum of human knowledge available in their pocket, answering any question in seconds. They're fluent in both worlds.

At five, Windows 95 came out with its startup sound and its Start button and commercials featuring the Rolling Stones. Families probably got a computer within a year or two—a beige tower with a CRT monitor that weighed forty pounds and made that high-pitched whine only kids could hear. They learned to type on a physical keyboard, navigate with a ball mouse that needed cleaning, wait patiently while pages loaded over dial-up that screamed every time it connected.

At eight, Google launched. Before that, finding things online required AltaVista, Yahoo directories with their categories and subcategories, or Ask Jeeves pretending to be a butler. The concept of 'just Google it' didn't exist. Neither did the assumption that all information should be instantly accessible. They remember when not knowing something was just a normal state of being that could last hours or days.

At eleven, the iPod debuted—a thousand songs in a pocket seemed miraculous when they'd been burning mix CDs one at a time. At fifteen, YouTube launched. At sixteen, Twitter went public. At seventeen, the iPhone dropped and everything that came before looked prehistoric. Within three years, smartphones were everywhere. Within five, they were mandatory. They watched the transition happen in real time, remembering exactly when their life got absorbed.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

This cohort was born into a world being rapidly remade. The Cold War ended before they could walk. Germany reunified in October 1990, two countries becoming one after 45 years of division. The Soviet Union collapsed eighteen months after their birth, dissolving into fifteen countries overnight. Parents grew up with nuclear annihilation as a real possibility, duck-and-cover drills, fallout shelter signs. This generation grew up wondering what all those signs were for.

The Gulf War started when they were six months old. It was the first war televised in real-time—CNN's ratings soared as Wolf Blitzer became a household name, green night-vision footage made bombing look like a video game. Parents probably watched while children slept. They don't remember it, but it set the template for how America would conduct and consume war for the next three decades: packaged, produced, distant.

At five, the Oklahoma City bombing killed 168 people, including children in a daycare center—domestic terrorism before that phrase was common. At eight, Princess Diana died and the world watched her funeral. At ten, Columbine happened—the school shooting that created the template for all the school shootings after, the media coverage pattern, the blame games, the lockdown drills that became standard. This generation normalized hiding in closets and staying quiet. That wasn't a feature of childhood before them.

They were eleven on September 11, 2001. Everyone knows where they were—everyone does. The wars that followed became background noise for their entire adolescence.

At eighteen, Lehman Brothers collapsed and the economy cratered. College freshman, watching the job market they planned to enter evaporate on the evening news. At twenty-five, marriage equality became law. At twenty-six, Trump won. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world. History kept accelerating, each crisis arriving before they'd recovered from the last.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Graduation from high school came in 2008—the year Lehman Brothers collapsed, the year the economy imploded, the year entry-level jobs vanished like morning fog. Those who went to college graduated around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, which was supposedly recovery but didn't feel like it. The job market had technically improved but the entry-level positions still required three to five years of experience, which was impossible without entry-level positions.

This generation entered the workforce right as the rules were being rewritten. Pensions were already extinct—dusty relics from grandparents' era. Job security was a quaint concept from parents' time. The gig economy was being sold as 'flexibility' and 'entrepreneurship' when it was really just 'we don't want to provide benefits or stability.' They adapted because adaptation was the only available option.

They've probably had more jobs by thirty-four than their parents had in their entire careers. Not because they're disloyal or restless—because companies stopped being loyal first. They watched colleagues get laid off two weeks after company-wide emails celebrating 'our people are our greatest asset.' They learned early that corporate promises mean exactly nothing, that 'we're like a family' is a red flag, that the only job security is the ability to find the next job.

Remote work became normalized during COVID, which was probably the one silver lining of that catastrophe. They proved they could do their job from anywhere, that productivity didn't require surveillance or commutes or fluorescent lighting. But employers interpreted that as 'you can do your job from everywhere, all the time, including weekends and vacations and 11 PM when Slack pings.' The boundary between work and life didn't blur—it dissolved entirely.

Their career has been shaped by economic trauma in ways that don't always serve them now. They're excellent at doing more with less, at stretching budgets, at being 'scrappy.' They're terrible at asking for raises because the implicit threat of unemployment hangs over every negotiation. They've internalized scarcity even when they're no longer scarce.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

This generation came of age during the dating app revolution. Tinder launched when they were twenty-three—young enough to adopt it naturally, old enough to remember what came before. They've experienced both meeting people organically—at parties, through friends, in college, at bars—and treating romance like a card game where they swipe based on four photos and a bio that might be ironic or might be sincere, impossible to tell.

Many probably met at least one significant partner online, which parents find bewildering ('You met on the computer?') and younger cousins find completely unremarkable ('Where else would you meet?'). They're the bridge generation—old enough to remember the vulnerability of asking someone out face-to-face, the specific heartbreak of being rejected while standing right there. Young enough to have normalized rejection via silence, the date that never responds, the match that disappears.

This generation texted more than called, but they still remember calling—actual phone conversations that lasted hours, the intimacy of voice when texting wasn't an option. They know the anxiety of read receipts, the micro-analysis of response timing, the paralyzing interpretation of punctuation choices. Is 'ok' passive aggressive? Is 'lol' genuine? Does the period mean they're mad? Communication became archaeology.

Millennials delayed marriage longer than any previous generation. Not from commitment-phobia but from arithmetic. Weddings cost $30,000 average. Houses cost half a million in any city with jobs. Student loans still accruing interest decades after graduation. The life timeline their parents assumed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—isn't available at any price. They're not immature. They're priced out of the milestones.

Their friendships span time zones because everyone moved—for work, for school, for cheaper rent, for somewhere that felt like it might offer more than wherever they started. Group chats replaced geographic proximity. They know how to be intimate with people they rarely see in person, maintaining closeness through memes and voice notes and occasional video calls where everyone talks over each other. They also know how to be distant from people they see every day. Connection became complicated.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

At ten, the dot-com bubble burst—abstract at the time, something adults discussed while children worried about fifth grade. At eighteen, the 2008 financial crisis, which was not abstract at all. College freshman year, watching the economy they planned to enter explode on live television. At thirty, the COVID economic collapse. This generation has watched the economy collapse three times before turning thirty-five. This shapes their relationship with money in ways that don't always make sense to people who haven't lived through the same education.

They save compulsively because they've seen how fast stability vanishes. A job loss, a medical bill, a recession, a pandemic—any of them can reset everything they've built. They also spend impulsively sometimes because what's the point of saving when the goalposts keep moving? They're simultaneously frugal and fatalistic. They'll skip the latte but splurge on experiences because the house they're saving for costs twice what it did five years ago and will cost twice that again in another five.

Student loan debt is probably a defining feature of their financial life. The average Millennial with student loans owes around $40,000. Payments stretch for decades. Interest accrues faster than they can pay it down. The promise was that education would pay for itself—that a degree was an investment that would return dividends. The promise was a lie told by people who'd paid $500 a semester.

Homeownership—the traditional wealth-building path that worked for every generation before them—has been largely inaccessible. The median home price is now over eight times the median income. Their parents bought houses for two or three times their annual salary. They're being asked to spend a decade's worth of wages, assuming they can save a down payment while rent takes 40% of their income.

They've been lectured about financial responsibility by generations who bought their houses before they were born. 'Stop buying lattes,' they say, as if $5 a day is what stands between them and $400,000. They're not bad with money. The math is broken, and no amount of budgeting fixes a rigged equation.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's biggest weakness is mistaking awareness for action. They're extraordinarily skilled at identifying problems—systemic racism, climate change, economic inequality, institutional failures. They can articulate them in threads, infographics, and think pieces. They're less skilled at the boring, grinding work of fixing them. City council meetings go unattended. Local elections have embarrassing turnout. The hashtag feels like participation. It usually isn't.

They've gotten so accustomed to broken systems that they've stopped questioning whether they should exist at all. They've normalized healthcare tied to employment as if that makes sense. They've accepted that education requires decades of debt as if that's inevitable. They've treated retirement as a fantasy rather than a policy failure. They've learned to cope with dysfunction instead of demanding change. Adaptability became resignation wearing a self-deprecating smile.

They're conflict-averse in ways that cost them money, dignity, and opportunities. They've been trained to be collaborative, to not make waves, to bring solutions instead of problems. This makes them exploitable in professional settings. They'll work unpaid overtime for 'experience.' They'll accept equity instead of salary because 'we're a startup, we're family.' They'll stay in toxic situations because leaving feels like failure and the job market is brutal and they need health insurance.

Their irony and self-deprecation sometimes prevent genuine advocacy. They can't just care about something—they have to care about it ironically, or defensively, or with layers of protective distance that prevent vulnerability. This makes demanding change feel cringe. Earnestness feels naive. They hedge everything, including their own needs, undercutting themselves before anyone else can.

They're so online that they sometimes forget offline is where stakes become real. They can mobilize millions of views on social media, but changing policy requires showing up to boring meetings in person. Developing the self-awareness to distinguish between feeling engaged and actually creating change may be this generation's most important work.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2010-2020): Graduation came into the long toxic tail of the Great Recession. Entry-level jobs required experience they couldn't get without entry-level jobs—the classic catch-22 of this generation. They probably moved for work, or moved back home, or did both at different points. This decade was supposed to be exploration and self-discovery. Instead, it was figuring out how to survive an economy that didn't particularly want them. They made it work. They always make it work. But the making it work came at a cost they're still calculating.

The 30s (2020-2030): They're in this decade now, a pandemic arriving right as it started—which felt about right. They've accumulated some stability—better salary, clearer career direction, maybe a partner, maybe kids. But the stability feels fragile in ways previous generations didn't have to experience. One medical emergency, one layoff, one economic crisis away from losing years of progress. They're building on foundations that keep shifting. This is the decade where they're supposed to have figured things out. The secret is nobody has.

The 40s (2030-2040): Statistically, this will be the peak earning decade. Institutional authority, professional expertise, the kind of leverage that only comes from experience and scars. But they'll also be sandwiched—aging parents who need care, kids who need support, a body that's started negotiating instead of complying. They'll be managing everyone else's needs while their own get back-burnered. This is the decade where they either consolidate the gains of their thirties or pivot entirely. Most people don't pivot. Most people should consider it.

The 50s (2040-2050): By now they'll have survived at least four major economic crises, probably two pandemics, and countless 'unprecedented' events that arrive every few years now. Pre-retirement age but probably unable to retire—the numbers won't work. Mentoring younger people who don't understand their scars, who can't imagine a world before smartphones, and catching themselves sounding like the people they used to dismiss. That's how it goes.

The 60s and beyond (2050+): Retirement, if it happens, won't look like their parents' retirement—the pension, the leisure, the gold watch. It'll involve part-time work, careful budgeting, maybe reliance on children who are struggling themselves. Social Security may or may not exist in recognizable form. Climate change will have reshaped geography. The world will be unrecognizable from the one they were born into. They'll tell younger people what life was like before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was connected and tracked. They'll have trouble believing it.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1990. They're part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest generation until Gen Z surpasses it, which will happen soon.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): Millennials are more educated—and more indebted because of it. Gen X got into the housing market before prices exploded into absurdity. They got stable jobs with pensions and benefits before stable jobs became rare. They inherited a functional economy and proceeded to pull up the ladder behind them, often without realizing what they were doing. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is significant. When Boomers were the same age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. Millennials control 7%. Boomers paid for college with summer jobs—actual jobs, not unpaid internships. Millennials took on mortgage-sized debt for the same degrees from the same institutions. Boomers bought houses for two times their annual salary. Millennials are priced out at eight times. They retire with pensions and Social Security. Millennials are hoping those programs survive until they qualify.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Millennials are similar in values but different in expectations. They remember a pre-9/11 world, however hazily—the optimism, the assumption that progress was inevitable. Gen Z doesn't have that memory. Millennials believed the system could be reformed through participation. Gen Z assumes it's broken and is building workarounds instead. Millennials adapted to smartphones as a teenager. Gen Z was born fluent in them. Millennials have hope, buried deep. Gen Z has nihilism, occasionally interrupted by hope.

Life expectancy for Millennials is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to rising rates of suicide, overdose, alcohol-related disease. This generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before. More anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world they inherited was harder and lonelier than the one promised in those optimistic '90s speeches.

But they're also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than generations before. They've normalized therapy and destigmatized struggling. They've pushed for equity in ways their parents' generation didn't prioritize. They inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That tension between progress and precarity is their generational legacy.

year_events: Germany reunified after 45 years of division
Nelson Mandela was released after 27 years imprisoned
Hubble Space Telescope launched into orbit
Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web
Gulf War began with Operation Desert Shield
